intro: Laserpitium gallicum f. paradoxum, commonly known as the French grass vetch, is a rare and distinctive plant belonging to the Fabaceae family. It is characterized by its slender, erect stems and small, pea-like flowers that typically bloom in late spring. The plant is native to parts of Europe and is often found in disturbed soils or along roadsides. Its foliage is usually finely divided, giving it a delicate appearance, and it is notable for its unique floral structure. Due to its limited distribution and specific habitat requirements, it is considered a rare and endangered species in some regions.
